Our house (townhouse condo) was built in the mid-1980s. We live in one of those planned communities that some people love to hate. BUT we have two sets of pipes. The toilets go to the sewer system and everything else goes to the local reclaimed water plant. We get that water back and use it for irrigation. The only downside- the kids can not run through the sprinklers because the water is not potable.
From now on all new construction needs to have the same system.
No more using drinking water for irrigation of any kind. We need to conserve and start building desalination plants.
Instead of letting water go only to the rich (by pricing it high) lets have a per capita water allotment.

That said it is easy to say no more water for agriculture until you realize that California is the largest agricultural economy in the US. IF CA were its own country its total economy would be ranked in the top ten in the world. We need to make changes but what would people all over the country eat next winter if all the farms dried up this summer?

Our nation's healthcare industry commands 18% of our nation's economy.   All the other developed nation's use 12% or less of their nation's economy.  Conversely, our nation's agricultural industry produces more food with resources applied than any other nation, by a wide margin.  Putting aside that the two industries represent enormously different industrial tasks, is it possible that there is an inherent fundamental difference between the two industries.  One of the two industries has a nationally created, institutionally defined connection between the producers and their training process and the other industry does not.  No amount of venture capital or other improvements for institutional governance will change the inadequate level of training offered to a physician at the beginning and extending throughout a career as a Primary Physician.  Our nation has a need for equitably available and culturally accessible health care for the Basic Healthcare Needs of each citizen.  Without a renewal of our medical education for Primary Health Care, there is NO hope that the efficiency and effectiveness or our nation's healthcare industry can be improved.  Isolated examples of supreme innovation will continue to shine and burn.  But, our nation's maternal mortality ratio will continue to worsen, now ranking at 37th of the 43 developed nation's of the world.  We would need to reduce our ratio by 80% to rank among the best 10 nations of the world, viz., 4 million births in 2013.

I have never understood the whole "tipping" wage argument. As far as I'm concerned, the management should be required to pay at LEAST full minimum wage. My tip represents my desire to reward EXCELLENT service OVER AND ABOVE that minimum. The idea that the management uses the tip revenue to "gross up" the employees wages to minimum wage is a misdirection of funds. If I wanted to tip the management, I would do so.

A salesperson is guaranteed their commission once the sale has been made. The restaurant worker receives no such assurance. Tipping is voluntary. Frankly, it steams my clams that management can take money that I earmarked for a specific individual and that I wanted to be distributed as a bonus above their minimum hourly wage, and use it to "gross up" their pay to equal the mandated state minimum. It strikes me as completely unethical and places tremendous pressure on the server and the customer.

Tips USED to be incentive pay....TIP = To Insure Promptness. It was a reward for great service. Now tips are seen as a mandatory thing to give to bring employee wages up to the minimum wage so the employers can still get away with paying them just over $2 an hour. Tipped jobs should have a base salary of at least minimum wage.  Tips should be an additional bonus given for exceptional service, not just given because the employee depends on it to make up the difference between their pay and minimum wage.  It offends me when a restaurant automatically tacks on 18% tip to a bill - especially when the service is horrific. It is not the diners responsibility to make sure the employee is making minimum wage. Also, it is not the same as commission, many commissioned jobs pay a realistic base salary of much more than $2 an hour.

While still millions of employers pay substantially less than minimum wage to tipped employees. No one in America should have to depend on kindness of others, in the form of a "tip" to make up the difference to get to the current minimum wage. Before we push for a higher minimum wage...how about making sure every worker in America is covered under the existing standard?

Water from agriculture does not end up in the water table. Irrigation and other practises tend to increase salinity levels in the soil and lowers the water table which over times reduce agriculture yields and renders prime farmland useless in certain areas. It has impacted on a substantial amount of our best farming land. The only thing that recharges ground water is rain and lots of if. There are other methods such as covering water channels and dams to reduce the effects of evaporation. We were encouraged at one point to recycle bath water, water off washing machines and proposals were looked at recycling water from sewerage on its way to deep open outfalls. To make it usable for water not drinking consumption this grey water would need to be filtered. My country is not desert as portrayed in the Middle East but Australia is one of the driest continents in the world. A few years ago and it seems to go in cycles we had a major drought in Sydney. We also have a rising population and population encroachment into our water catchment areas. It seems to me you have to educate your people through media and other campaigns on how to conserve water and make whatever water you have last a bit longer. The rain will come and your dams will fill again. It is only a matter of when.

Don't neglect those big trees. Give them water at the expense of everything else. The big trees provide oxygen essential to lessening air pollution where you live. The big trees roots are fed by water from lawn watering.

Las Vegas has already proven, over the last 10 years, that removing sprinklered lawns kills the big trees which provide oxygen to clean the air. Trees are dying all over Clark County from lack of water and the air quality is getting worse.

Any meat-ax approach by the government is going to kill California's urban area trees, and you are going to be back to the reality of Johnny Carson area smog jokes.

I live in Sacramento.  We have had limitations on water use since last year. We can only water lawns and landscaping twice a week, and only before 10:00 a.m. and after 7:00 p.m. Not supposed to let water run off. Not supposed to wash sidewalks. I forget what it is about washing cars--mine is tan and doesn't show the dirt and I don't think I washed it more than once last year.  First violation is a warning. After that, you can be fined up to $1,000.  When running water until it gets hot enough for a shower or for dishes, I catch it in a container and use that in the already low-water-using new toilet or pour it on shrubs or the lawn. I'm not sure what more some of us individuals can do.  We have 40 year old trees that provide shade for the house, and they need water, too. I would like to see golf courses, cemeteries, public parks, and school campuses let their lawns go brown.  Last year there were a lot of local news reports of poorly-maintained sprinklers on public property sending lots of water down the drains.
Remove cotton, almonds and rice from the California agriculture mix. Other sources for these crops can be located. They are too water intensive.
